text: when you see the commercials about like
pull this rope see how far your
retirement will take you you're like
what are you I'm not even thinking about
that and it's oh well let me let me take
it back it's not that I'm not thinking
about that it doesn't seem touchable
like that really could be what its tax
season again a young married couple
visits an accountant for guidance about
filing jointly it's a new experience for
them I didn't grow up in a family that
was able to talk about money and like a
productive and healthy normal way I
don't even know what that's like but so
having access to that information we
walked that was like I think I need a
glossary of terms crystal and Claudia
are working to build a solid financial
foundation for themselves and their
young son malaya crystal works in human
resources while Claudia is a social
worker and family therapist although
they've been married for two years this
is the first year that same-sex spouses
will be able to file federal taxes like
any other married citizens one couple
have been doing their tax return for a
few years they've been married and it
was extremely complicated last year and
this year I told him we're filing you
like any other married couple it's not
going to be complicated gonna be a lot
easier and he started to cry he's like
who would have thought this little gay
farmer boy from Arkansas would ever be
treated like every other married couple
he said I never thought I'd ever hear
those words the only thing is Janice
Kelly Macdonald leads the LGBT practice
and Markham LLP she's volunteered to
speak to crystal and Claudia about their
taxes as the federal government legally
recognizes same-sex marriages it's
changed how employers deal with same-sex
couples we got this letter in the mail
saying due to this change in federal
regulation these are you know these
taxes are now being refunded to you and
it felt very it felt like we were being
recognized yes
oh that is this year Claudia and crystal
will benefit from filing jointly but
many same-sex couples will end up paying
more in taxes as a result of their newly
recognized status if you have disparity
income somebody's a high wage earner and
somebody is a stay-at-home parent or an
unemployed parents you'll definitely
benefit by finally marry joint if you're
too high wage earners you're going to
get hit with the marriage penalty tax
and pay a significant amount more in
taxes so when you ready to buy a house
this young couple may be among the few
who get some joy out of dealing with the
IRS but they face additional
complications as same-sex parents when
dealing with other bureaucracies like
insurance companies or when traveling
out of state the policies still don't
reflect the needs that our families
continue to struggle with like health
insurance and you know helping us to
create our families and protect them
this is Mack William Bishop reporting
for the New York Times
